title: Golden Ticket in the Toy Workshop
stem_md:
In a bustling toy workshop, the foreman announces a **golden ticket** will be awarded to the first worker whose **paint color** matches one used by any previous worker that day. Each worker randomly selects from $365$ unique paint pots (uniform probability, no repeats unless by chance). You can choose your position in the worker queue. 

At which position $n$ should you stand to maximize your chance of winning the golden ticket?
hints: Hint 1 – Your win requires two things: all prior workers used distinct colors, AND your color matches one of theirs.
Hint 2 – The probability has two parts: (1) the chance the first $n-1$ workers all picked different colors, and (2) your color matches one of those $n-1$.
Hint 3 – Compare $P(n)$ to $P(n-1)$ and $P(n+1)$ to find where $P(n)$ peaks. Solve the inequalities $P(n) > P(n-1)$ and $P(n) > P(n+1)$.
detailed_solution_md:
Let $P(n)$ be the probability you win as the $n^{th}$ worker. This requires:
1. First $n-1$ workers all pick distinct colors: $$\frac{365}{365} \times \frac{364}{365} \times \cdots \times \frac{365 - (n-2)}{365} = \frac{365!}{(365-(n-1))! \cdot 365^{n-1}}$$
2. Your color matches one of theirs: $$\frac{n-1}{365}$$

Thus, $$P(n) = \frac{365!}{(365-(n-1))! \cdot 365^{n-1}} \times \frac{n-1}{365}$$

To find the optimal $n$, compare adjacent terms:

**Step 1:** Write $P(n-1)$, $P(n)$, and $P(n+1)$:
$$P(n-1) = \frac{365!}{(365-(n-2))! \cdot 365^{n-2}} \times \frac{n-2}{365}$$
$$P(n) = \frac{365!}{(365-(n-1))! \cdot 365^{n-1}} \times \frac{n-1}{365}$$
$$P(n+1) = \frac{365!}{(365-n)! \cdot 365^{n}} \times \frac{n}{365}$$

**Step 2:** Set $P(n) > P(n-1)$ and simplify:
$$\frac{P(n)}{P(n-1)} = \frac{(365-(n-2)) \cdot (n-1)}{365 \cdot (n-2)} > 1$$
$$\Rightarrow (365 - n + 2)(n - 1) > 365(n - 2)$$
$$\Rightarrow -n^2 + 3n + 363 > 0$$
$$\Rightarrow n^2 - 3n - 363 < 0$$

**Step 3:** Set $P(n) > P(n+1)$ and simplify:
$$\frac{P(n)}{P(n+1)} = \frac{(365-(n-1)) \cdot n}{365 \cdot (n-1)} > 1$$
$$\Rightarrow (365 - n + 1)n > 365(n - 1)$$
$$\Rightarrow -n^2 + n + 365 > 0$$
$$\Rightarrow n^2 - n - 365 < 0$$

**Step 4:** Solve inequalities:
- From $n^2 - 3n - 363 < 0$, roots are $n \approx 20.8$ (positive root). Range: $n < 20.8$.
- From $n^2 - n - 365 > 0$, roots are $n \approx 19.1$ (positive root). Range: $n > 19.1$.

**Conclusion:** The integer $n$ satisfying both is $\boxed{20}$.
